Methods Seventy patients with Cierny-Mader stages III and IV chronic osteomyelitis admitted to the Department of Orthopedics of a Class III Grade A Hospital from January 2018 to March 2022 were selected for retrospective analysis and study. The following patient data were collected: gender, age, site of infection, bacterial culture results, internal fixation status, bone defect length, BMI, history of diabetes mellitus, smoking history, and history of preoperative antibiotic use. The patients were treated with sensitive antibiotics after surgery, followed up regularly, and venous blood C-reactive protein (CRP), sedimentation (ESR), white blood cells (WBC) and muscle strength (MTT scale), joint mobility (neutral 0° method), and bony healing time were measured to observe the recurrence rate of osteomyelitis and to assess the recovery of limb function according to the Enneking scale. Results Among the 70 patients, 20 cases were guided by X-ray, 30 cases by MRI, and 20 cases by SPECT. All patients underwent thorough debridement under the guidance of imaging modalities followed by external fixation. All cases were followed up and with a mean follow-up time of (12.2 ± 3.2) months. The recurrence rate of 35% in patients with X-ray as a guide was significantly higher than that of patients with MRI as a guide (10%) and SPECT as a guide (5%), and the difference between the three groups was statistically significant ( P Conclusion For patients with osteomyelitis without metal internal fixation, the osteotomy surgical technique with MRI to guide the expansion of 0.5 cm distally and proximally, or with SPECT imaging to guide the surgical procedure in the area with 30–40% of the radioactive count contour (isocontour, ISO) had the advantages of low recurrence rate and good recovery of limb function, and the differences were not statistically significant. For patients with osteomyelitis with metal internal fixation, the osteotomy surgical technique with SPECT to guide the surgical procedure had the advantages of low recurrence rate and good recovery of limb function. In patients with osteomyelitis with metal internal fixation, SPECT was used as a guide to determine the extent of the osteomyelitis lesion, and osteotomy in the area with 30–40% of ISO was more effective than MRI. X-ray guided osteotomy was performed in 20 patients in group A, MRI guided osteotomy was performed in 30 patients in group B, and SPECT guided osteotomy was performed in 20 patients in group C. The differences in general conditions between the two groups were not statistically significant ( P n n n n n n n Diagnostic criteria (1) history of trauma and fracture; (2) local erythema, pain, and sinus tracts with repeated pus flow; (3) laboratory tests, relevant imaging examinations, and intraoperative tissue bacterial culture and pathological tests, clearly diagnosed as Cierny-Mader stages III and IV chronic osteomyelitis. Inclusion criteria (1) Those who met the above diagnostic criteria and were infected after traumatic fracture surgery; (2) those who had chronic osteomyelitis by intraoperative tissue sampling for pathological examination; (3) those who had Cierny-Mader stages III or IV; (4) those who were in good physical condition, without major medical diseases and could tolerate surgery; (5) those who agreed to undergo surgical external fixation treatment. Exclusion criteria (1) those with incomplete follow-up data; (2) those patients who follow up with shedding. Treatment method After the patient was admitted to our hospital, the relevant examinations were completed, and a bacterial culture and drug sensitivity test were performed with the secretion of the sinus tract, and the anti-infection treatment was started after screening for sensitive antibiotics. Preoperatively, the extent and length of the osteotomy were determined based on the patient’s imaging data. In group A patients, the contour of the osteosclerotic area was used as the standard for osteotomy until the “red pepper” sign was observed with fresh blood leakage (Fig. 1 2 3 4 5 Fig. 1 X-Ray image and osteotomy range of osteomyelitis Fig. 2 MRI image and osteotomy range of osteomyelitis Fig. 3 SPECT image and osteotomy range of osteomyelitis Fig. 4 SPECT image and osteotomy range of osteomyelitis Fig. 5 Picture of a surgical osteotomy Observation indexes and evaluation criteria  Inflammatory index testing After the operation, we followed up every two weeks in the outpatient clinic, and measured venous blood inflammatory indexes CRP, ESR and WBC and recorded the data.  (2) Functional evaluation One month after the operation, X-ray films were taken to observe bone growth, and functional assessment was performed, including muscle strength (MTT scale), joint mobility (0° in neutral position), and final bone healing time was recorded. The patients’ limb function recovery was also assessed according to the Enneking scale (excellent: 24–30 points; good: 19–23 points; acceptable: 12–18 points; poor: <12 points). Primary endpoint: Recurrence-free status at 1 year postoperatively, defined as absence of localized erythema/swelling, sinus tracts, normalized CRP/ESR levels, and no radiographic evidence of new osteolytic lesions. Secondary endpoints: Time to radiographic bone union and achievement of Enneking score ≥ 19 (indicating good or excellent functional outcomes).  (3) Recurrence rate Recurrence of infection was based on local symptoms and signs, such as sinus tract formation, exudation, erythema, and X-ray manifestations, as well as systemic symptoms, such as elevated CRP and ESR, and fever. Statistical analysis SPSS 26.0 (IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY, USA) software was used for statistical analysis. Quantitative data were statistically analyzed by t-test and one-way ANOVA, and count data were statistically analyzed by χ2 test and Fisher’s exact test. Analysis of potential recurrence risk factors (BMI, diabetes, smoking history) revealed no statistically significant intergroup differences in baseline distribution ( P P The impact of preoperative antibiotic therapy remains underexplored in this study. Although 82.9% of patients received ≥ 2 weeks of preoperative antibiotics, we did not analyze its association with recurrence due to the uniformity of postoperative negative cultures and the lack of standardized antibiotic regimens. Notably, 72.4% of these patients received broad-spectrum β-lactams, which may have contributed to transient suppression of subclinical infections without eradicating biofilm-embedded pathogens. Future prospective studies should stratify patients by antibiotic duration and spectrum to clarify this relationship. X-rays are the most widely used diagnostic imaging technique and can be used as a preliminary examination for chronic osteomyelitis [ 13 22 23 25 24 26 27 3 Through this study, it was found that determining the extent of osteomyelitis debridement based on MRI and SPECT greatly reduced the recurrence rate of osteomyelitis compared with X-ray, and that SPECT was more advantageous in the presence of metal internal fixation. However, there are still recurrence cases in this, and the reasons for this are summarized as follows: (1) inadequate flushing during surgery, resulting in residual dead bone; (2) poor imaging of soft tissues by SPECT, resulting in incomplete removal of surrounding necrotic tissue; and (3) possible re-infection due to irregular postoperative dressing changes. In conclusion, this study summarizes a clinical treatment standard based on MRI and SPECT to determine the extent of lesion clearance in Cierny-Mader stages III and IV chronic osteomyelitis, which is of practical significance to establish osteomyelitis treatment standards. Several limitations should be acknowledged. First, the study did not analyze the impact of bacterial infection types (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus vs. Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and preoperative antibiotics on recurrence rates, as the primary focus was imaging-guided osteotomy techniques, but we found that the detection rate of Staphylococcus aureus was the highest, reaching 52%. While postoperative cultures were uniformly negative, preoperative bacterial profiles may still influence treatment outcomes through variations in biofilm formation or antibiotic resistance patterns. This exclusion limits our understanding of potential microbiological confounders and should be addressed in future studies. This paper lacks sufficient analysis of the interaction between internal fixation and other factors, which is a limitation of this study. We will take this as a starting point for subsequent research. The absence of time-to-event analyses for recurrence and survival endpoints warrants further investigation through multicenter trials with extended observation periods.
